div1.p:
Consulate General of the United States
Republic of Liberia

J Milton Turner
to the
Department of State
Washington U.S.A.
Subject:
Transmitting copy of protest of Messrs Pettengill and Everett, Agents for Messrs Mansfield and Roberts of Boston.
Inclosures:

No. 1 Copy of note from Messrs Pettengill and Everett.
No. 2. Copy of protest of Messrs Pettengill and Everett.
No. 3. Reply of Mr Turner to Messrs Pettengill and Everett

St Louis, State of Missouri
November 29th, 1876
Sir:

I have the honor to transmit herewith for the information of the Department, marked inclosure No. 1. a copy of a note which was received by me at this place, today, conveying to me from Messrs Pettengill and Everett, agents at Salt Pond, West Coast of Africa, for Messrs Mansfield and Roberts of Boston Massachusetts, the protest of the said Pettengill and Everett against a decision rendered by certain courts of Her Majesty's colonial settlements of Sera and the Gold Coast, West Africa. It appears that the protest refered to, was originally addressed to the Legation at Monrovia, and sent thence under date of September 23, through mistake, with my personal letters to my address at this place. A copy of the protest of Messrs Pettengill and Everett, as well as a copy of my reply to their note to me from accompaniments with
Honorable
John L. Cadawalder
Assistant Secretary of State
Washington
with this despatch, and are marked inclosure No. 2. and inclosure No. 3., respectively

I have the honor to be
Sir:
With high consideration and esteem,
Your obedient servant
J. Milton Turner
P.S.
Sir
The Boston firm refered to written are Messrs Roberts and Mansfield; and not Mansfield and Roberts as stated in the body of this despatch.

Very respectfully
Your obedient servant
J Milton Turner

Salt Pond West Coast Africa
4th July 1876

To the Honorable
U.S. Minister at Liberia

We the undersigned American citizens doing business in the Gold Coast West Coast Africa as Agents for Messrs Roberts and Mansfield of Boston, there being no U.S. Counsil or Commercial Agent on the Coast and sharing no where means of getting redress humbly beg to submit to you notice a copy of what we consider unjust treatment by the Courts of the Colonial Goverment hoping you will give it your early and favorable consideration.

We beg to inform you that a Copy of one protest has been sent to the Secretary of State at Washington, one to the Colonial Governor at Cape Coast and one to Messrs Roberts and Mansfield Boston owners of the vessel.

We
We have the honor to remain
Your very Obediant Servant
(sgd.) Pettengill and Everett

To the Honorable
U.S. Minister
Liberia

We James J Pettengill & Robert Everett agents on the West Coast Africa for the firm of Roberts & Mansfield Boston Mass U.S.A. having suffered much inconvenience and severe pecuniary losses in business. Through the "in one oppinion" unjust decision of the Courts at Cape Coast and Accru in the Mutiny Case of the Bark Bolivia of Boston and in Subsequently taking the chief mate by force from same vessel, discharging him and compelling the master to pay his passage home by steamer, do by this protest and petition against the acts and decision of the Courts in the above cases and trust your Excellency will take an early opportunity of ascertaining the particulars of the case and give us the same Justice as would be accorded to British subjects in a British Court.

First "We object to the decision of the Court at Cape Coast
in trying the crew of the American Bark Bolivia acused of mutiny" for simple assault and after being found guilty by the Jury having been discharged by the Court without passing any sentence and ordered to be discharged from the vessel, when as it is our oppinion they should have been returned to the vessel to complete the voyage.

Second "We object to the acts and decision of the Court at Accra in taken the Chief Mate out of the sad vessel on a summons for debt, as we believe it is according to law, that payment can not be collected for debt contracted by any sailor belonging to any ship unless the contraction of the debt was sanctioned by the master.

We further object to a doctor in the service of the Colonial Government giving the said Mate a certificate stating he is sick and must go home and then the same doctor going into Court in the capacity of magistrates and acting Judge and compelling the Master of said vessel to discharge said Mate pay his debts and send him home by steamer.

We object to the second case because even supposing the Mate to have been very sick and needed to go home, we had at that very time a vessel ready to leave for the the United States and might have saved expenses, moreover we are of oppinion that the Court exeded it
